statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: LSU 90, Auburn 69
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- LSU used Auburn's game plan against them. LSU hit from the perimeter and kept Auburn from getting into rhythm from its favorite distance for a 90-69 victory Wednesday night. "There whole team shoots from the perimeter," said Darrel Mitchell. "So we knew we had to stay on them and keep them from making them. That's how we won the game." Mitchell and Tack Minor each scored 17 points to lead LSU to the victory. LSU (13-7, 6-3 Southeastern Conference), took the lead early in the first half and never let Auburn get close again, leading by as much as 29 in the second half. Auburn (11-11, 2-7) was unable to guard LSU. LSU shot 56.9 percent from the field, had only seven turnovers and scored 20 points off Auburn's 14 turnovers. "They're too good inside," said Auburn coach Jeff Lebo. "So our only chance to beat them was for them to miss some perimeter shots. They were making them from the perimeter and inside they were terrific." LSU beat Auburn inside, scoring 40 points in the paint to Auburn's 28, and outside, making 9 of 17 3-pointers. "I thought defensively we got out to the 3-point line to take away their threes," LSU coach John Brady said. "They never got into a rhythm of making baskets." LSU had five players in double figures. Brandon Bass and Antonio Hudson each scored 15 and Glen Davis hit for 12. "We played good team ball and had good chemistry," Bass said. "We put what we practiced into the game and got the win." Nathan Watson led Auburn with 19 points, Toney Douglas had 18 and Ian Young added 14. Auburn's first-year coach Lebo has gotten the most out of his small, speedy lineup by going with a perimeter-heavy attack this season. Auburn went into the game with the second-most 3-pointers made (180) in the SEC this season. Against LSU, Auburn made 8 of 23 3-pointers (34.8 percent). LSU, which had struggled from that distance this year, shot 52.9 percent long range (9-17). LSU also made 15 of 20 free throws. "It's tough guarding those guys," Watson said. "They are huge inside. We don't have that size. They are very strong and very had to guard." LSU was up 51-34 at halftime. Both teams started slowly in the second half. Mitchell hit a 3-point basket to open the scoring. Auburn did not get on the board for almost four minutes when Daniel Hayles' layup pulled Auburn to 54-36. LSU, winners of seven of its last nine games, is 11-1 at home this season.
